title: Relational Time-of-Arrival as a Covariant Field Observable: From Event Currents to a Continuum Clock Limit
description:
The definition of time observables in quantum theory remains conceptually unsettled. In nonrelativistic quantum mechanics, Pauli-type arguments obstruct the existence of a self-adjoint time operator conjugate to energy, while in relativistic quantum field theory (QFT) localization, causality, and observer dependence further complicate the notion of time-of-arrival (TOA). Existing approaches—such as POVM-based constructions and detector models—are operationally effective but typically depend on specific measurement schemes or preferred time parameters.

This work introduces a relational and manifestly covariant formulation of time-of-arrival in QFT. Rather than postulating a universal time operator, TOA is defined as a field-functional constructed from two conserved structures:
(i) a conserved matter current encoding detector crossings, and
(ii) a conserved event current whose integral defines a discrete event-count clock.

Under controlled coarse-graining, the discrete clock admits a continuum limit described by a scalar clock field governed by an effective field theory (EFT). This provides a unified ultraviolet–infrared hierarchy linking integer-valued event counts to smooth clock readings, while remaining compatible with Hamiltonians bounded from below.

A general relational TOA distribution is derived by binning detector flux with respect to the physical clock field evaluated on the detector world-tube. The resulting observable is covariant and independent of detector microphysics up to the detector geometry and matter current. In a worked 1+11+11+1-dimensional example, the TOA distribution appears explicitly as a convolution of the semiclassical matter flux with clock-sector correlations, yielding predictive arrival-time broadening. The variance is fixed by clock fluctuations, while early-arrival contributions are shown to be exponentially suppressed with a scale determined by the clock-sector mass parameter.

An appendix derives this exponential envelope from standard massive propagator asymptotics, clarifying the distinction between local (Gaussian) clock noise and nonlocal correlation bounds. A concrete realization motivated by Swirl-String Theory (SST) is presented as an example, identifying the event current with defect worldlines and the clock field with a foliation scalar, though the relational construction itself remains model-independent.

The framework isolates a sharpened notion of detector-independence and provides a predictive, falsifiable program for time-of-arrival observables in relativistic quantum theory, with direct applicability to analytical and numerical studies across resolutions.

Keywords

time of arrival; relational time; quantum time observables; covariant observables; event currents; quantum field theory; effective field theory
